2 We must therefore approve the opinion of Arrian, when he con- demns* the revenge of Alexander upon the Persians, since those who had wronged the Greeks were long ago dead. Concerning the dc- struction of the Branchidae by the same Alexander, the judgment of Curtius is simila-r, that it ‘evas not justice, but cruelty, to punish those who could not betray Xeroees, and had never seen Dliletus. And of the same kind is the judgment of Arrian respecting the burning of Perse- polis, that there was no true punishment init, since the offending Persians had long ceased to be.
